caption_original: Located on a peninsula jutting out into Lake Erie, Point Pelee is not only the southernmost national park in Canada, it‚Äôs the very southern tip of the country itself. Point Pelee is also home to a whopping 66 species at risk ‚Äì more than any other national park in the country. This includes the monarch butterfly, a species threaten by extreme weather and habitat loss. Point Pelee is working to restore the savannah areas that provide vital habitat for the monarch. #LearnAboutButterfliesDay

Anne of Green Gables fans may recognize Dalvay-by-the-Sea as the fictional ‚ÄúWhite Sands Hotel.‚Äù It was featured in the Anne of Green Gables movies and in the television series Road to Avonlea. Tomorrow is Dr. Norman Bethune‚Äôs 127th birthday! During the early 20th century, Dr. Bethune became a medical pioneer, advocate for Canada‚Äôs universal health care system, and revered Chinese cultural icon. Take a tour of Bethune Memorial House National Historic Site, a charming Victorian-era home set on a manicured property alongside an informative Visitor Centre, and immerse yourself in an incredible legacy of accomplishment that strengthens the bond between nations to this day. http://www.pc.gc.ca/eng/lhn-nhs/on/bethune/visit.aspx

caption_original:
At 44,807 km2, Wood Buffalo National Park is Canada‚Äôs largest national park and one of the largest in the world! The park was established in 1922 to protect the free-roaming bison herds of the area. Today, the park supports and protects many unique natural and cultural resources, like the nesting habitat of the last remaining wild migratory flock of whooping cranes left in the world. 

To celebrate #Canada150, we‚Äôre featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Stay tuned!

caption_original:
Happy birthday to Elk Island National Park!  

With elk, mule deer and moose enclosed within its fenced boundaries, Elk Park became the first federally controlled area in Canada to be enclosed as a big game sanctuary. Elk Island Park, as it was called in 1908, was a wildlife park until it became formally designated as a Dominion Park on this day in 1913! 

To celebrate #Canada150, we‚Äôre featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Stay tuned!

A landscape and history as diverse as the day is long awaits you at Grasslands National Park, one of our hidden gems to explore in 2017!

With over 70 different species of grass and over 50 different species of wildflowers, Grasslands has an important role in protecting the prairie ecosystem! Discover some of Canada‚Äôs rarest wildlife, darkest skies, astonishing dinosaur fossils, over 12,000 teepee rings and varied landscapes, from buttes and valleys to breathtaking badlands.

To celebrate #Canada150, we‚Äôre featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Stay tuned!

caption_original: ‚ÄúWhat in the world are national parks?‚Äù was Mabel Williams‚Äô response when she first heard of protected parks. In the 1920s, she went on to explore the parks by foot, by horse, and by car, as research for her guidebooks that became the decade‚Äôs centrepiece of tourism promotion for the parks, the Canadian Rockies, and Canada itself. The best job on earth, if you ask us! #EqualityMatters #InternationalWomensDay

caption_original: It's Unique Names Day! There are many national parks with very special (and sometimes hard to say) names, like Kouchibouguac National Park. Pronounced koo-she-boo-gwak, it means "river of long tides" in Mi'kmaq, where fresh and salt water meet. Learn more about what's in the names of our national parks: http://ow.ly/xane3093WWd

It's #NamesakeDay! Did you know that many of our national historic forts and national parks have namesake merchant vessels? Among others, Banff Park, Cape Breton, and Green Gables Park, named quite evidently after one of Canada's most popular heroines! These vessels contributed to securing Allied victory in 1945, a legacy with which Parks Canada is proud to associate. 

Library and Archives Canada
Royal Canadian Navy

caption_original: It‚Äôs National Frozen Food Day! Did you know flash-freezing technology was inspired by Inuit ice-fishing practices in Canada? Rock caches are a traditional means of storing food in the North. Natural gaps in between rocks channel air flow, acting like a coolant, to keep food fresh or frozen. Tuktut Nogait National Park is home to an area called ‚ÄúMany Caches,‚Äù where you can find, you guessed it, many, many caches! Who knew areas like this are to thank for your modern-day frozen dinners!
caption_cleaned: It‚Äôs National Frozen Food Day! Did you know flash-freezing technology was inspired by Inuit ice-fishing practices in Canada? Rock caches are a traditional means of storing food in the North. Natural gaps in between rocks channel air flow, acting like a coolant, to keep food fresh or frozen. Who knew areas like this are to thank for your modern-day frozen dinners!

caption_original:
Join us in commemorating the service and sacrifice of Canadians during the First World War. 

Today, historic plaques were unveiled by Minister McKenna to recognize the national historic significance of Aboriginal Military Service during the First World War, the Voluntary Aid Detachments and the Canadian War Memorials Fund. 

Their important contributions during WW1 helped define who we are as a people today.

caption_original: All her life, Katharine McLennan nurtured a deep passion and commitment towards the history and preservation of the Fortress of Louisbourg in Cape Breton, where she was from. For years, she did extensive research to help tell the story of Louisbourg, and, after World War I, she was at the forefront of a civil group aiming to preserve the Fortress of Louisbourg site. Their work led to the opening of the Louisbourg Museum in 1936 and the partial reconstruction of the Fortress in the 1960s. Katharine was named "Honorary Curator" of the museum and served in this capacity for over twenty years. #EqualityMatters #InternationalWomensDay
caption_cleaned: All her life, Katharine McLennan nurtured a deep passion and commitment towards the history and preservation of the Fortress of Louisbourg in Cape Breton, where she was from. For years, she did extensive research to help tell the story of Louisbourg, and, after World War I, she was at the forefront of a civil group aiming to preserve the Fortress of Louisbourg site. Their work led to the opening of the Louisbourg Museum in and the partial reconstruction of the Fortress in the s. Katharine was named "Honorary Curator" of the museum and served in this capacity for over twenty years.
